BIL GRAVE VIEWS ADMISSIONS
An interview with the Director
of Admissions at Johns Hopkins
University, Robert Bilgrave, has
revealed that (1) it's getting
much more difficult to gain admission to Johns Hopkins; (2)
engineering isn't the overwhelmingly popular field many seem to
think it is.
The freshman class entered in
1958 numbered 397; that in 1959,
417. Next September's entering
class will probably approximate
400. In that same period, however, applications have almost
doubled. In 1957-58, high school
seniors sent 1184 applications in
the direction of Hopkins; in
1958-59, 1524 applications; in
1959-60, 1829; and the final count
for 1960-61 will reach about
2100.
Thus, Hopkins freshman population remain approximately
the same, though three hundred
more students each year attempt to gain admission.
This three-year survey of admissions also reveais a paradox,

both in the nationwide admissios picture and in that of Hopkins. Up till three years ago, the
number of engineers was keeping
pace with that of other groups;

ROBERT BILGRAVE

two years ago, however, there
was a 7% increase in freshmen
throughout the nation; at the
same time there was about an
11% decrease in engineers. Last
year there was a 5% increase in
over-all students; in engineering, a 4% decrease.
At Hopkins, this has meant
that the number of students applying and indicating a interest
in engineering has remained
about the same the last couple of
years (April, 1959-376; April
1960-380) whereas as applicants
in all other fields have shown a
marked increase. The greatest
percentage increase in applications has come from students
showing an interest in the humanities and the social sciences.
This reflects Dr. Milton Eisenhowers acknowledged desire to
see Hopkins get more and better
students in thee fields; and the
success of the Public Relations
Office's Weekly Newspaper column.

Why has engineering seemingly declined? Bilgrave cited three
factors: (1) all the adverse publicity given engineering in regard
to opportunity and advancement; (2) other areas, particularly the physical sciences, are
becoming more attractive to the
boy who would normally apply.
for engineering; and (3) the
general stiffening of the engineering curriculum. At Hopkins
this last factor has been exemplified by the requirement that
engineers carry three electives
along with their usual math and
science Courses.
Returning to the question of
increased difficulty in getting admitted into Hopkins, Bilgrave
noted that in the past, a boy's
being chosen by Hopkins rested
upon whether or not he was admissible; now, all the people who

Lectures Students
On Khrushchev
Mrs. Frances Humphrey Howard, sister of presidential hopeful
Hubert Humphrey and Executive
Director of the United Nations
Association of Maryland, was
the guest speaker at a Student
Council Conference at 10 o'clock
this morning in the Clipper Room
of Shriver Hall. The address was
entitled "The Challenge of Nikita
Krushchev to America."
Mrs. Howard received academic
training in Sociology at George
Washington University, in Public
Administration at American University and in International Relations at Johns Hopkins University, McCoy College.
For the past few years, she has
spent time interpreting the role
of the United Nations. She has
given more than 250 speeches on
the work and activities of the
U.N. and has produced over 45
T.V. shows on U.N. affairs and
United States Foreign Policy.
In 1959 she lectured an eightweek course at the Johns, Hopkins University, McCoy College,
entitled "Can the United Nations
Meet today's Challenge?"

BIL GRAVE VIEWS ADMISSIONS
An interview with the Director
of Admissions at Johns Hopkins
University, Robert Bilgrave, has
revealed that (1) it's getting
much more difficult to gain admission to Johns Hopkins; (2)
engineering isn't the overwhelmingly popular field many seem to
think it is.
The freshman class entered in
1958 numbered 397; that in 1959,
417. Next September's entering
class will probably approximate
400. In that same period, however, applications have almost
doubled. In 1957-58, high school
seniors sent 1184 applications in
the direction of Hopkins; in
1958-59, 1524 applications; in
1959-60, 1829; and the final count
for 1960-61 will reach about
2100.
Thus, Hopkins freshman population remain approximately
the same, though three hundred
more students each year attempt to gain admission.
This three-year survey of admissions also reveais a paradox,

both in the nationwide admissios picture and in that of Hopkins. Up till three years ago, the
number of engineers was keeping
pace with that of other groups;

two years ago, however, there
was a 7% increase in freshmen
throughout the nation; at the
same time there was about an
11% decrease in engineers. Last
year there was a 5% increase in
over-all students; in engineering, a 4% decrease.
At Hopkins, this has meant
that the number of students applying and indicating a interest
in engineering has remained
about the same the last couple of
years (April, 1959-376; April
1960-380) whereas as applicants
in all other fields have shown a
marked increase. The greatest
percentage increase in applications has come from students
showing an interest in the humanities and the social sciences.
This reflects Dr. Milton Eisenhowers acknowledged desire to
see Hopkins get more and better
students in thee fields; and the
success of the Public Relations
Office's Weekly Newspaper column.

Why has engineering seemingly declined? Bilgrave cited three
factors: (1) all the adverse publicity given engineering in regard
to opportunity and advancement; (2) other areas, particularly the physical sciences, are
becoming more attractive to the
boy who would normally apply.
for engineering; and (3) the
general stiffening of the engineering curriculum. At Hopkins
this last factor has been exemplified by the requirement that
engineers carry three electives
along with their usual math and
science Courses.

increased difficulty in getting admitted into Hopkins, Bilgrave

being chosen by Hopkins rested
upon whether or not he was admissible; now, all the people who
